name: Pale Panther
text_html:
White with black spots, this serpentine wavekin looks like the typical panther might after its observer has pressed their fists to their eyes for some time─an action that naturalists stress is not recommended. While it moves with the speed one would expect of a carnivore, due to its poor eyesight coupled with the near nonexistent light deep below the surface, it is sadly inept at finding prey.

Item Description:

A variety of eel with a monochrome pattern covering its body.

[Suitable for printing on medium canvases.]

name: Saltsquid
text_html:
A squid that grows to enormous size thanks to the abundance of minerals that amass in the depths of its high-salinity environment. While favored by local Highlanders for its nutritious flesh, most find this loch-dweller too salty for their tastes.

Item Description:

A massive squid that calls Loch Seld home.

[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]

name: Platinum Hammerhead
text_html:
With eyes on either side of its protruding head, this predator misses none of what happens deep in the loch. It rules its waters with a fist more iron than platinum, hunting down the prey it sets its bulging eyes upon to the very end.

Item Description:

The apex predator of the lochs, this shark can be found skimming the depths in search of prey.

[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]

name: Othardian Wrasse
text_html:
Small sky blue dots pattern this creature's otherwise monochrome body. While its few larger black markings may be suspected of camouflaging the true location of its eyes, they in fact are a by-product of this fish's aether-sensitive organs, and─rather dangerously─mark said organs' position.

Item Description:

A saltwater creature known for its beautiful coloration.

[Suitable for display in aquariums tier 2 and higher.]

name: Shogun's Kabuto
text_html:
With a head shape eerily reminiscent of a samurai's helmet, it is no surprise that warriors once attempted to don this fish's skull as a form of protection. One will also not be shocked to hear that it was far from effective, being easily penetrated by enemy katana.

Item Description:

So curious is the shape of this creature's skull, one cannot help but want to wear it.

[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]

name: Pipefish
text_html:
Inhabiting the coral reef and its neighboring sands, this creature peeks out from its abode to expose the white, arrow-shaped pattern on its head only once in a blue moon. Though it lacks many a spot compared to the garden eels it so resembles, it at least shares their bulging and slightly confused eyes.

Item Description:

A long, red saltwater wavekin embellished with a white underbelly.

[Suitable for printing on small canvases.]

name: Xiphactinus
text_html:
Primordial beings with glimmering teeth so sharp as to earn them the name “blade's ray.” Known to hunt birds in addition to other fish, they propel themselves through the surface with powerful strokes before their prey gets any hint of danger.

Item Description:

Since time immemorial, this creature has terrorized waterways with its piercing teeth and powerful jaw.

[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]

name: Kitefin Shark
text_html:
A leisurely shark partial to life at the bottom of the seas. While many mistakenly believe it to have skin tougher than armor, this is but a misnomer wrapped in an old wives' tale. Though comparably inflexible for a creature of the deep seas, when brought ashore, its hide is far from what it is cracked up to be.

Item Description:

A shark with shining, surreal eyes that stand out like gems against the dull background of its body.

[Suitable for display in aquariums tier 3 and higher.]
[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]

name: Tebqeyiq Smelt
text_html:
A small tropical fish that inhabits the coral reefs off of Tebqeyiq. Males boast bright blue and yellow patterning to court females, which keep to an arguably drab grey-black.

Item Description:

For every vivid specimen of this species found, there is another far less interesting to look upon─but such is the nature of tropical fish.

[Suitable for display in aquariums tier 1 and higher.]
[Suitable for printing on small canvases.]

name: Inksquid
text_html:
Among the cephalopods found in salt lakes, this particular wavekin boasts the largest ink sac despite its diminutive size. Treasured as a delicacy in Gyr Abania, its ink is well known for the abundant minerals contained within it, and its pungent kick is ever a delight to those whose family traditions involve a nice lick of licking salt.

Item Description:

Found deep within salt lakes, this cephalopod earned its name by virtue of the copious amounts of ink it produces.

[Suitable for printing on medium canvases.]

name: Auroral Clam
text_html:
According to Far Eastern legend, this clam emits light of comparable beauty to that which radiates from the very goddess of auroras herself. A coveted ingredient for mother-of-pearl inlays, some believe that simply adorning tableware with its shell will improve the taste of food, a flimsy theory Sharlayan cuisine has put to the proof time and time again.

Item Description:

Shimmering like an aurora, the unparalleled beauty of these clams have spawned no small few myths among divers in the Far East.

[Suitable for printing on small canvases.]

name: Ken Kiln
text_html:
Though the waters surrounding the Isle of Ken can sink to frigid temperatures, this freshwater fish thrives by generating copious amounts of body heat. This internal aetheric reaction is far more than simple thermoregulation, however, as the flesh of this creature retains its uncanny heat even after trimmed and gutted.

Item Description:

A species of large trout known for its ability to remain snug and warm at all times.

[Suitable for printing on medium canvases.]

name: Glorianda's Tear
text_html:
This bivalve mollusk is of such a clear and delicate color, it perfectly resembles an errant petal plucked from a flower in the blush of spring. Perhaps this is why the pixies were so quick to name it for their forebear Glorianda, in imitation of the Jenanna's tear of Longmirror Lake.

Item Description:

Named for the legendary Forebear of Pixies, this small shellfish is so beautiful it oft brings literal tears to the beholder's eyes.

[Suitable for printing on small canvases.]

name: Verdigris Guppy
text_html:
This wavekin's mottled green pattern gives it the impression of being clad in weathered bronze─a perception not far from the truth. Its scales, suffused by the mineral waters of Bronze Lake, are known to contain traces of rare metal.

Item Description:

A fish prized not only for its green mottled beauty, but for the rarity of materials its body provides.

[Suitable for display in aquariums tier 1 and higher.]
[Suitable for printing on small canvases.]

name: Lakeskipper
text_html:
Known─and named─for its unique style of swimming, this freshwater fish skips rapidly from rock to rock as it traverses the lake floor. It does this not for the sheer joy of living, but to inflict a swift, unpredictable death upon the smaller wavekin that it hunts for food.

Item Description:

This small freshwater fish is aptly named for its unique, prancing movement across the bottom of Bronze Lake.

[Suitable for printing on small canvases.]

name: Bronze Eel
text_html:
Legend has it that this smooth-scaled eel of dark bronze came into existence only after a lancer hurled a slain comrade's spear into the lake. The story fails to mention whether the lancer was ever aware of this miraculous genesis, or if it sparked a craze of submerging postmortem mementos in large bodies of water.

Item Description:

Despite having achieved a perfect shade of bronze, this slender and snakelike fish understands better than anyone that there is always room for improvement.

[Suitable for printing on medium canvases.]

name: Striped Peacock Bass
text_html:
This member of the peacock bass family is recognizable for its bold stripes, the deep green markings a stunning reflection of the lake's emerald waters. Spearfishers consider this fish one of the region's prize catches.

Item Description:

Whether the stripes are meant to be attributed to the peacock or bass is still largely up for debate amongst many ichthyologists. Regardless, this moderately sized and greenish fish is quite lovely.

[Suitable for printing on medium canvases.]

name: Bronze Trout

The scales of this distinctive trout range from a deep olive green to a gleaming bronze brown. Its crimson flesh is highly sought after by fishermen, who equate the darker hue with a richer─and thus more expensive─flavor.

This large freshwater fish has indeed come to resemble its eponymous lake after long years of inhabiting its waters.

This “unexpected predator,” as naturalists have dubbed it, is a surprisingly harmonious cog in the local ecology. Despite its prehistoric appearance, the massive nosceasaur appears to consciously avoid disrupting the food chain's delicate equilibrium.

This huge scalekin is believed to have inhabited the waters of La Noscea since time immemorial.

name: Empyreal Spiral
text_html:
An abundant mollusk, the empyreal spiral is the source of many of Saibai Cavern's beautiful shells and, in turn, its name. The shells have long been used in the artisanal works of Sui no Sato─in particular, a pigment that shimmers with rainbow hues.

Item Description:

Though equally beautiful intact, this conch shell becomes an in-demand pigment when ground to pieces, so pulverized it shall be.

Named for its scales' resemblance to the multicolored gemstone, this freshwater fish is enchanting to behold. Whether it is aware of its own beauty has yet to be determined.

The imposing dorsal fin of this freshwater fish earned this fish its fearsome appellation.

name: Zeh Lar Dor
text_html:
The array of mottled colors adorning this wavekin are the basis for its name. In the Yok Huy tongue, “Zeh Lar Dor” means “the fish that shines with every color from the depths of the earth to the farthest reaches of the night sky.”

Item Description:

The body of this large wavekin is wreathed with an array of complex markings.

[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]

name: Karvarichthys
text_html:
The Yok Huy creation myth speaks of a spirit guide appearing in the form of a giant wavekin. Given its size and ancient lineage, scholars believe this fish may have some connection to the legend.

Item Description:

This looming wavekin has inhabited the depths of Karvarhur the First since ancient times, remaining, for the most part, unchanged.

[Suitable for display in aquariums tier 3 and higher.]
[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]

This wavekin is said to be a discarded torch come to life, fated to roam the waters forevermore.

This timid wavekin would rather you didn't find it lurking in the depths of Lake Toari.

[Suitable for printing on large canvases.]
